translated: Birth Stories
The Book of Elevens
The Chapter on Mother’s Keeper
The Birth Story of Juṇha
“Listen to my words, lord of the people,
I’ve come here for a reason.
While the extra brahmins are standing,
You should go, best of two-legged beings.”
“I listen, I stand, speak, brahmin,
For what reason have you come here?

analyzed: kam vā tvam attham mayi patthayānaḥ
translated: What benefit do you hope for from me,

analyzed: idha agama brahme tat iṅgha brūhi
translated: Having come here, brahmin, tell me that.”
“Give me five of the best villages,
A hundred female slaves, seven hundred cows,
More than a thousand gold coins,

original: Bhariyā ca me sādisī dve dadāhi.
analyzed: bhariyā ca me sādisī dve dadāhi
translated: And two wives equal to me.
Are your austerities terrifying, brahmin,

analyzed: mantā nu te brāhmaṇa citta rūpā
translated: Are your mantras pleasing, brahmin?

original: Yakkhā nu te assavā santi keci,
analyzed: yakkhā nu te assavā santi keci
translated: Do you have any obedient spirits,
Or do you know of any benefit for me?”

original: Na me tapo atthi na cāpi mantā,
analyzed: na me tapaḥ atthi na ca api mantā
translated: “I have no austerities and no mantras,

analyzed: yakkhā api me assavā natthi keci
translated: I have no obedient spirits at all,
And I don’t know of any benefit for you,
But before, we had a mere connection.”
I know this meeting of ours,
But I do not know of any other before this.
Tell me, when questioned, the reason for this,

original: Kadā kuhiṁ vā ahu saṅgamo no.
analyzed: kadā kuhim vai ahu saṅgamaḥ naḥ
translated: Where and when did we meet before?

analyzed: gandhāra rājassa puramhi ramme  avasimhase takkasīlāyam deva
translated: In the delightful city of the Gandhara king,🔽I was living in Takkasila, O god,
In the darkness of the night, in the gloom,
I rubbed my shoulder against yours.

original: Te tattha ṭhatvāna ubho janinda,🔽Sārāṇiyaṁ vītisārayimha tattha;
analyzed: te tattha ubhaḥ janinda  sārāṇiyam vītisārayimha tattha
translated: There, standing together, O lords of men,🔽We exchanged greetings;
That was our only meeting,

original: Tato na pacchā na pure ahosi.🔽Yadā kadāci manujesu brahme,
analyzed: tatas na pacchā na pure ahosi  yadā kadāci manujesu
translated: There was nothing more before or after.
When, O Brahmā, a meeting with a good person occurs among men,
The wise do not destroy the bonds of friendship,
Even what was done in the past.
But fools destroy the bonds of friendship,
Even what was done in the past;
Much that is done for fools perishes,

original: Tathā hi bālā akataññurūpā.🔽Dhīrā ca kho saṅgatisanthavāni,
analyzed: tathā hi bālā a kataññu rūpā  dhīrā ca kho saṅgati santhavāni
translated: For fools are ungrateful.🔽But the wise do not destroy the bonds of friendship,

analyzed: pubbe katam vā api na na āsayanti
translated: Even what was done in the past;

analyzed: appam pi dhīresu katam na nassati
translated: The wise man’s little deed is not lost,

analyzed: tathā hi dhīrā su kataññu rūpā
translated: For the wise man is grateful.
I give you five choice villages,
A hundred female slaves, seven hundred cows,
And a thousand pieces of gold,

original: Bhariyā ca te sādisī dve dadāmi.
analyzed: bhariyā ca te sādisī dve dadāmi
translated: And two wives equal to you.

original: Evaṁ sataṁ hoti samecca rāja,🔽Nakkhattarājāriva tārakānaṁ;
analyzed: evam satam samet ca rāja  tārakāna
translated: Thus, O King, you will be equal to me,🔽Like the moon among the stars;
I am the lord of Kāsi, you are the lord of Kosala;

analyzed: tayā api me saṅgamaḥ ajja laddhā uti
translated: Today I have obtained your company.”
The Jataka of the Star-King (Jūjaka) is finished.
